body: bind doesn't support multi-gpu. Use mx.mod.Module instead

@qcl6355 Yep. I've already used `DataIter` for data loading. 

Here's my plan on the second, I prepare the first, static, channel with an embedding layer initialized with word2vec. The embedding layer is used to generate `(batch_size, 1, sentence_size, num_embed)` input. The second is identical to the first, then `concat` them into `(batch_size, 2, sentence_size, num_embed)` as input before `conv`, but only update on the second non-static layer using some fine-tuning tricks as mentioned here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/2242

Oh I see, thank you!

I have altered the code to use mx.mod like so - the code runs but on the CPU.

I think I messed up the kvstore param?

```
ctx = [mx.gpu(int(x)) for x in range(4)]
mod = mx.mod.Module(cnn, context=ctx)
mod.bind(data_shapes=[('data', DATA_SHAPE)],
         label_shapes=[('softmax_label', (BATCH_SIZE,))])
mod.init_params(mx.init.Normal(sigma=SD))
mod.init_optimizer(kvstore='local',
                   optimizer='sgd',
                   optimizer_params={
                       "learning_rate": 0.01,
                       "momentum": 0.9,
                       "wd": 0.00001,
                       "rescale_grad": 1.0/BATCH_SIZE
                   })
metric = mx.metric.Accuracy()
for epoch in range(EPOCHS):
    for batchX, batchY in load_data_frame('amazon_review_polarity_test.csv',
                                          batch_size=BATCH_SIZE, 
                                          shuffle=True):
        # Wrap X and y in DataBatch (need to be in a list)
        batch = DataBatch(data=[batchX], label=[batchY])
        # Push data forwards and update metric
        # For training + testing
        mod.forward(batch)
        mod.update_metric(metric, batch.label)
        # Get weights and update
        # For training only
        mod.backward()
        mod.update()
```
After load the model. Get its params and find the embedding layer, you can get its parameter there.
use kvstore='device"
@javelinjs , I am wondering how much of the Scala Api will be changed, for example,  if using code generation to get the operator, will it break the compability with the old version ?
@jermainewang This is already handled via broadcast_add etc. any idea on directly redirect to these functions?
Does it also handle other stuffs like sub/div/mul/maximum/minimum ?
yeah, check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/broadcast_reduce_op-inl.h#L429
I guess actually they should be here https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/elementwise_binary_broadcast_op-inl.h

Ok, does that means we now have two `broadcast_to` in the code? One is defined in python another in c++. I will switch to the c++ version. Please correct me if i'm wrong. I will use the c++ `broadcast_to` combined with the `ufunc_helper` for all the `ufunc` function in python. Am I correct?

@tqchen I see. This code seems to have many redundant parts... It does not support maximum/minimum. The current way of adding this in python is here: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L608
It seems cleaner.

The c++ code enjoys being one step without resorting to broadcast_to, which I think should be preferred if available. Otherwise, the current way of resolving things is fine.

In either case, we should use the newer broadcast_to in c++ side.

I mean I agree use the `broadcast_to`. But the broadcast_plus and broadcast_mul just looks like monsters. It is much cleaner and easier to use the ufunc_helper in python to add new ufunc ops. I will keep it in the python right now until we have a easier way of defining ufunc with broadcast in c++.

Same Problem with pre-built20160531 on my win7 64bit and CUDA8.0 RC, CUDNN5, VS2013. Also passed cuda samples' matrix multiply.

I'm going to back to 20160223 and see if it works.
I think backwardmul/div/pow etc can now be merged with function template with auto return type since we support c++11 with nvcc now.

@jermainewang The python `broadcast_to` is implemented by calling the C++ version https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L309-L331

We can simplify the code in the C++ side and add `max/min` and `broadcast_max/broadcast_min`.
@antinucleon, @jennyzhang0215 and I have implemented MemN2N and NTM and replicated the results in the paper, we may release the code after AAAI or WWW. I can send you the code if you need now.
@LiamZhuuu You can use the no-bias mode and add a constant bias by yourself.

Ok, I think the correct way to do this is still using the [`ufunc_helper`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L554) in python side. It accepts an argument `fn_array` which is a function to be called when both operands are of type `ndarray`. In current `mx.nd.add` implementation, it uses [`_internal._plus`](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/ndarray.py#L625) for this argument. We could directly use `broadcast_plus` here for this function and remove the call to `broadcast_to`. This seems to be the minimal way of changing. What do you think @tqchen ?

And another problem for the c++ version broadcasting. It does not support:

```
a = mx.nd.ones((3,))
b = mx.nd.ones((4, 3))
c = a + b
```

This is a valid broadcasting with left padding. It fails here: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/elementwise_binary_broadcast_op-inl.h#L57

The point is if we want the behavior to the same as `numpy`. We'd better allow this.
Changes like this shold be good.
@javelinjs For the 2nd point, we can consider resgistered "kill child process action" in ShutdownHook , then PS scheduler and Servers  preocess will exit immediately as Spark Driver or Executor stop.
@Ldpe2G Sure, we need to keep it compatible with the old.
Also, I saw issue #1804 saying that CSVIter does not support data parallelism, does this mean that it will not support computation with several GPUs?

I made some advances:

``` R
CustomIter <- function (data.csv, data.shape, batch.size, shuffle=FALSE) 
{
  vocab_size <- data.shape[1]
  feature_len <- data.shape[2]
  csv_iter <- mx.io.CSVIter(data.csv=data.csv, data.shape=c(1,feature_len), batch.size=batch.size)
  csv_iter$iter.next()
  vect <- as.array(csv_iter$value()$data)
  data <- array(0, dim=c(vocab_size,feature_len,1, batch.size))
  format(object.size(data),units='auto')
  for(b in 1:batch.size){
    for(f in 1:feature_len){
      data[vect[1,f,b],f,1,b] <- 1
    }
  }
  label <- array(0, c(1,batch.size) )
  custom_iter <- mx.io.arrayiter(data=data, label=label, batch.size=batch.size, shuffle=shuffle) 
}
```

This returns a custom iterator, it is not very efficient. However, I'm having problems when training the net. I got `[1] Train-accuracy=NaN`. Am I doing the right thing?

Without BN layer, the two output vector is not exactly the same. To one image, if both train and test run on GPU, the Euclidean distance of output vectors is exactly zero, if train on GPU and test on CPU, the distance is about 10e-1 to 10e-2. If with BN layer, the distance is about 10e8 to 10e10.
The writer does not write prediction in the example. see #2938 for more infomation and the issue is help for me.
Don't change metric.get(). Use get_name_value in compositemetric instead

Hi, all. In order to help others who may run into this problem. I fix the error by creating a soft link as below:
cd /usr/lib64
ln -s libcblas.so.3 libcblas.so

thanks all for discussion.
Thanks - interesting. It runs on the GPUs but is slower than just one GPU

32, 4 gpu should use 128

@antinucleon Thanks for the help, so I have set the globals like so:

```
GPUS = 4
ctx = [mx.gpu(int(i)) for i in range(GPUS)]
BATCH_SIZE = 128 * GPUS
```

The params:

```
cnn = create_crepe()
mod = mx.mod.Module(cnn, context=ctx)
mod.bind(data_shapes=[('data', DATA_SHAPE)],
         label_shapes=[('softmax_label', (BATCH_SIZE,))])
mod.init_params(mx.init.Normal(sigma=SD))
mod.init_optimizer(optimizer='sgd',
                   optimizer_params={
                       "learning_rate": 0.01,
                       "momentum": 0.9,
                       "wd": 0.00001,
                       "rescale_grad": 1.0/BATCH_SIZE
                   })
```

And the training:

```
for epoch in range(20):
    t = 0
    metric.reset()
    for batchX, batchY in load_data_frame('amazon_review_polarity_train.csv',
                                          batch_size=BATCH_SIZE,
                                          shuffle=True):
        batch = DataBatch(data=[batchX], label=[batchY])
        mod.forward(batch, is_train=True)
        mod.update_metric(metric, batch.label)
        mod.backward()
        mod.update()
```

Yes, there is an option to control whether to normalize within channel or cross channel. It is committed in one recent PR.
@winstywang  Not yet. Running it now. is there any difference between ccSGD and SGD? (except for the c++ implementation)
@JohanCao Not sure. I heard some problems about ccSGD long time ago. I'm not sure whether it is related to your issue.
Try warm up with a smaller lr as stated in the paper.
use monitor to print stuff instead of inserting printf. example/python-howto/monitor_weight.py shows how to do it

1. use ccsgd optimizer instead of sgd
2. system memory doesn't reflect real usage of memory due to delayed release. Increase batch_size until OOM and compare the maximum viable batch_size to properly compare memory usage
3. AlexNet is a very simple network. There won't be that much memory saving. inception is a much better benchmark

I see your question. This is caused by the behavior change of BN layer from cudnn v4 to v5. In v4, it uses inv var, however in v5 it changes to var. So the moving_inv_var is only for cudnn v4, it is not used in current batch_norm.cu
@antinucleon Seems to be pooling shape issue
Thank you for your advice, and how to use ccsgd optimizer? Thank you very much.

Hi @piiswrong , i still have some doubts about sharing weights. Bellow is my stupide code:

```
    data1 = mx.sym.Variable("data1")
    data2 = mx.sym.Variable("data2")
    conv_weight = mx.sym.Variable("conv_weight")
    conv_bias = mx.sym.Variable("conv_bias")    
    conv_1 = mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data1, weight=conv_weight, bias=conv_bias, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=64)
    conv_2= mx.symbol.Convolution(data=data1, weight=conv_weight, bias=conv_bias, kernel=(3, 3), pad=(1, 1), num_filter=64)
```

I have to define two similar network with same weight, which is inefficient,  especially when the network is deep. Is there any simple way to make two same network share same weights just like

```
define network():
      ..........
net_1 = network()
net_2 = network()
share_weight(net_1,net_2)
net = mx.sym.Concat(net_1, net_2,)
```

I just experienced the same problem.  The solution is selecting the right compiler for your OS architecture ("Win32 or x64") as discussed here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33097558/cmake-cuda-libraries-not-found-when-compiling-opencv 

Try selecting "Visual Studio 12 2013 Win64" as your generator, and your problem should be solved.
After generate the optimized code,we can compile it into a DLL by some c++ compilers,then use Executer to execute the operations defined in the DLL.

code generation is an important feature. We were considering Halide.
But don't have the man power to do it right now. You are certainly welcome to work on this.
If you do want to pitch in, please keep us updated on your design decisions.

hi @xzqjack 
As mentioned in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/make/config.mk#L115,  please add caffe/build/lib to LD_LIBRARY_PATH in ~/.bashrc.
Then run "source ~/.bashrc" in terminal, problem should be solved.

in numpy, we can use something like:

```
shape = (10,100,9,9)
eps = 1e-10

a = np.ones(shape)
b = a / (np.sqrt(np.sum(a ** 2, axis=1))[:,np.newaxis,:,:] + eps)
```

in mxnet, the following code does not work since the corresponding part of `[:,np.newaxis,:,:]` is missing

```
a = mx.symbol.Variable(name='a',shape=shape)
b = a / (mx.sym.sqrt(mx.sym.sum(mx.sym.pow(a,2),axis=1)) + eps)
```

Is there any function support creating `newaxis` for a symbol?

I initialized the bias using gaussian as well.
I also tried to initialize the net with the model that I trained with matconvnet, after only one iteration, some layer weights and gradient are NaN. The initial learning rate is 1e-7.

After searching from various documents (#3080), I find [mxnet.symbol.expand_dims](http://mxnet.io/packages/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.expand_dims) and [mxnet.symbol.broadcast_div](http://mxnet.io/packages/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.broadcast_div) can do the trick:

```
a = mx.symbol.Variable(name='a',shape=shape)
b = mx.sym.broadcast_div(a, mx.sym.expand_dims(mx.sym.sqrt(mx.sym.sum(mx.sym.pow(a,2),axis=1)) + eps, axis=1))
```

However, the docs for `mxnet.symbol.broadcast_*` are still not very clear. And I still can't find any option for `mxnet.symbol.L2Normalization` to control whether to normalize within channel or cross channel.
I want to know either
It would be helpful if you can post your code
